title: Just admit the mistakes, Riot
body:
Look, as a kid you are taught that trying to cover up your mistakes only makes matters worse - you are eventually caught in an endless trail of covering and re-covering and re-re-covering the major cockup you made, and in the end, when you can't keep it up any longer, the result is far worse than if you had just said "Yeah, my bad. I'll fix that."

You've nerfed Syndra.  She didn't need a nerf.  She is now completely unviable.  You've nerfed Fizz, who needed a nerf, but it's pretty clear you've overshot his damage quite a bit to the point that his primary role is no longer his actually viable role (AD Bruiser Fizz is apparently now about the only thing you can reliably build on him).  You've given Ahri a power shift that gave her a new identity, but to such an extreme as never seen before (for those who don't know this, the speed boost Ahri gets on her Q throw is a flat 200+ MS at level 1, which is almost unreal in terms of just speed).  You are making mistakes left and right and are refusing to concede that maybe, just maybe, the mistake lies in the action you just took rather than something that was already existent in the champ.
It's admirable to stick to your guns sometimes.  Sure, it shows you're going to judge the merits of your actions on your own and aren't going to be dictated or controlled.  That's lovely.  But I'm going to take a wild guess and say that, out of the champs that your team plays at Riot, Urgot isn't exactly regularly picked up for that hour or two of mandatory play testing you have every day, or both teams aren't packing a Lee Sin in the jungle and so you wouldn't have an iota of a clue as to what it's like to be an out-of-the-meta champ facing the titan of the jungle.  Sometimes you're simply overlooking the parts that, while they aren't played by the vast majority, are played by that small minority that feel the ripples of the impact from your nerfs, and it's because you're not paying them any mind.
Well, here we are.  We're telling you what's wrong right now.  A lot of people here play your game far more in a month than you have time to within a year.  And while there are certainly the raging few that will complain about whatever is completely obnoxious to play against (I know I've done it once or twice), when there's post after post after post after post of what is absolutely unbearable in your game, ignoring the advice isn't "sticking to your guns".  That is just blatant, stubborn stupidity.  And right now, all signs point to the primary problem right now - some very, very, very mobile champs are being overbearing in the context of the game, and what you're doing is bringing the hammer down on champions that are already struggling, trying to bring them into a line that you drew on the opposite end of the spectrum - you are breaking champs by making them unviable, or just straight breaking champs.  Before you move to outright commit to something, why don't you take a bit longer time to just hold tight, observe, and see where that change will go?
And sometimes the change doesn't work out, and that's unfortunate.  But at not point should you feel that you can't just go "Yeah, that's not going to fly.  We're going to have to revert for a moment."  If you feel that you can't ever do that on something - that you straight just can't revert the changes you made - it's either A) because the champion was more broken before the change and you've made some legitimate progress, or B) you're just trying to sweep what you did away and pretend that it's all fine.
It isn't.  It isn't all fine.  Please own up to your bloody mistakes because you have been making a lot of them lately and are paying them about as much mind as my dog pays mind whenever he piddles on the carpet - clearly you're aware you've done something wrong, but the face you give makes you seem like you just don't want to admit it.

Reasons like this are why I could never get into game design, while there are people in the community who might know about one side of the situation, there are plenty they don't look after and at time don't really care about overall balance, they only care about what they care about. It isn't as easy as just listening to the forum goers because they aren't the majority, they are the vocal minority. 

Case in point, Hashinshin is a heavy advocate for melees, but he doesn't want them balanced, he wants them to outright dominate every other classes. Remember that post he made about Elixir of Iron being nerfed, he didn't point out why, or even give any counter argument, he simply whined saying that Riot plays favorites but ignored the fact that some champions were able to get WELL above the 35% tentacity.

So it is much less sticking to their guns and more about literally not being able to listen to the forums without creating a shit storm. "Oh, they listened to this person's idea, but not mine, da fuck, this champion didn't need buffs, nerfs, etc."

This is really good, but I would like to add that we are not the only boards, all the regions have their own and they're not all saying the same things. Also, they gather data from games that we are playing which in turn helps them decide what to balance.
I just want people to realize that it isn't as easy as they say and imagine it is.

Which is why I wish Riot would provide more input on their decisions. Instead of making funny comments in the patch notes and saying: "We want this, we thought this..." they should provide commentary IN THE PBE.
